title-group.article-title: Developments in the Phenomenological Reading of Durkheim's Work

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1981 The University of North Carolina Press

abstract.p: The opposition between phenomenological sociology and Durkeimian sociology is not as absolute as it is often presented. The various ways in which Durkheim's work has been read by phenomenological authors throughout the last fifty years testify to a development toward greater proximity, implying changes in phenomenologists' interpretation of Durkheim as well as in their own starting points. Beginning with an exposition of one of the most antithetical stands towards Durkheim, the article points out different phases of the aforementioned development: (1) A more or less total opposition; (2) A positive view of the challenged that phenomenologists can find a Durkheim's work and an attempt to incorporate it into their own viewpoints without really changing the latter; (3) A simultaneous reinterpretation of Durkheim's sociologism and the pehnomenological notions of subjectivity and intentionality, on the common basis of a renewed insight into the corporeal character of human social phenomena.

p.mixed-citation: This is the translation of a paper originally presented, under the title "Lecture phénoméno- logique de l'oeuvre de Durkheim," at the Ninth World Congress of Sociology, Uppsala, 1978 (R.C. 6: History of Sociology: Groupe d'etudes Durkheimiennes)Lecture phénoménologique de l'oeuvre de Durkheim Ninth World Congress of Sociology, Uppsala 1978
